liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In news just in, lawyers for former US president Donald Trump have proposed an April, 2026 date for the start of his criminal trial. Trump is facing charges related to alleged efforts to meddle in the 2020 election result in Georgia, a crucial swing state that helped Joe Biden win the White House. This is the fourth set of charges faced by the former president, and the second relating to election interference. Trump has until August 25 to voluntarily surrender to the office of Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, who is seeking a trial date in the next six months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump's lawyers propose 2026 trial date in election case

children.content: In news just in, lawyers for former US president
Donald Trump
have proposed an April, 2026 date for the start of his criminal trial.
Trump is facing charges related to alleged efforts to meddle in the 2020 election result in Georgia, a crucial swing state that helped Joe Biden win the White House.
This is the fourth set of charges faced by the former president, and the second relating to election interference.
Trump has until August 25 to voluntarily surrender to the office of Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, who is seeking a trial date in the next six months.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results. Unlike in federal and many other state cases, the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing. In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms". The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats. Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened. It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Threats have reportedly been made against jurors who voted to indict Donald Trump in Georgia

children.content: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller

Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results.
Unlike in federal and many other state cases,
the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing.

props.alt: A group of police and security personel standing outside of a courthouse

children.content: (AP: Ben Gray)
In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms".
The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats.
Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened.

It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events. AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup. The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029. But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition. Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP: "(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game. "There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia. "We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success. "We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: As the Matildas prepare for Sweden, Football Australia prepares to bid for more local events

props.alt: Sam Kerr smiles and gives a thumbs up while walking into the changerooms at a football stadium. Fans in the stands behind clapping

children.content: (Getty Images: FIFA/Maddie Meyer)
Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events.
AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup.
The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029.
But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition.
Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP:
"(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game.
"There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia.
"We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success.
"We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is going through quite the rollercoaster lately, but analysts at NAB have described it as a "doom loop", where one negative movement is cycling through the currency markets. For the unfamiliar, "doom loop" or ("urban doom loop") was coined by a professor at Colombia University to describe the downward spiral some cities are facing — like San Francisco, which is in the midst of an opioid crisis, high housing costs, and tech boom all at once. In layman's terms, it's a cycle of one negative condition feeding another negative condition, which feeds another negative condition, and so it goes. But NAB's head of markets, Ray Attrill, has plagiarised the term (his words, not mine) to describe what's currently happening in currency markets. He explained that the "ongoing appreciation" of the US dollar and Japan yen — which hit a new high of ¥146.56 overnight — is causing an aversion from China when it comes to the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen exchange rate (which is especially relevant given China and Japan are competing over manufacturing high-end goods like electric vehicles). Comparatively, the US dollar and Chinese yuan exchange rate hit its highest level since November 3 overnight, and that's ricocheted throughout the Asia-Pacific. It's that flow on effect that caused the NZ dollar to plummet to 59.03 US cents overnight, and sending the Aussie dollar down to 63 US cents (the lowest for both currencies since early November). Given the additional uncertainties China's economy is facing, we can expect to see this loop to continue for a while yet.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia's declining dollar has found itself in a 'doom loop'

In layman's terms, it's

, which feeds another negative condition, and so it goes.
But

, has plagiarised the term (his words, not mine) to describe what's currently happening in currency markets.
He explained that the "ongoing appreciation" of the US dollar and Japan yen — which hit a new high of ¥146.56 overnight —
is causing an aversion from China
when it comes to the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen exchange rate (which is especially relevant given China and Japan are competing over manufacturing high-end goods like electric vehicles).
Comparatively, the
US dollar and Chinese yuan exchange rate hit its highest level since November 3 overnight
, and that's ricocheted throughout the Asia-Pacific.
It's that flow on effect that caused the
NZ dollar to plummet to 59.03 US cents overnight
, and sending the
Aussie dollar down to 63 US cents
(the lowest for both currencies since early November).
Given the additional uncertainties China's economy is facing, we can expect to see this loop to continue for a while yet.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Latitude Financial has posted its half-yearly results to June 30 on the ASX this morning, with its CEO Bob Belan describing the first six months of the year "amongst the most challenging in Latitude's history". Back in March, the company disclosed it had been the target of a cyber attack that saw millions of Australians have their personal data compromised, and is considered to be one of the largest cyber breaches in Australian history. Latitude is reporting a statutory loss (after tax) of $98.2 million, which includes $76 million of "pre-tax costs and provisions relating to the March cyber incident". Its cash profit is also down 88% to $7 million. Compared to last year, cash net profit after tax came in at $86 million. In an investor presentation, Belan noted that the "cyber disruption" impacted their the volume of sales, but it is slowly picking back up. It noted that before the cyber attack in January and February, its volume was up 12.5%, and is down 3% year on year — but as of June this year, volume has returned to June 2022 levels. Latitude also notes that while it is now focused on safely restoring business operations, significant financial risks remain because of the cyber attack, including: Regulatory fines Legal claims and/or class actions Technology review The company has also told investors there will be no first-half dividend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Latitude Financial posts half-yearly $98m loss after cyber hack in March

children.content: Latitude Financial
has posted its half-yearly results to June 30 on the ASX this morning, with its CEO Bob Belan describing the first six months of the year
"amongst the most challenging in Latitude's history"
Back in March, the company disclosed it had been the target of a cyber attack that saw millions of Australians have their personal data compromised, and is considered to be
one of the largest cyber breaches in Australian history
Latitude is reporting a statutory loss (after tax) of $98.2 million
, which includes $76 million of "pre-tax costs and provisions relating to the March cyber incident".
Its
cash profit is also down 88% to $7 million
. Compared to last year, cash net profit after tax came in at $86 million.
In an investor presentation, Belan noted that the "cyber disruption" impacted their the volume of sales, but it is slowly picking back up.
It noted that before the cyber attack in January and February, its volume was up 12.5%, and is down 3% year on year — but as of June this year, volume has returned to June 2022 levels.
Latitude also notes that while it is now focused on safely restoring business operations,
significant financial risks remain because of the cyber attack
, including:
Regulatory fines
Legal claims and/or class actions
Technology review
The company has also told investors there will be no first-half dividend.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: No, you're not imagining it — Bitcoin took a very sudden nosedive and dropped by 7.2% to $US26,634 just before 8am AEST. The cryptocurrency has now lost more than $US2,000 from its previous close, and is down 16.3% from its highest level of $US31,818 on July 13. It's picked up slightly again, but is still around 5% lower and nowhere near where it was less than an hour ago — just check out the chart below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bitcoin nosedives by 7.2 per cent to $US26,600
